00040 #ifndef _physactor_h
00041 #define _physactor_h

00043 #include "physvector.h"
00044 #include "physquaternion.h"
00045 #include "physworld.h"

00047 ///////////////////////////////////
00048 // Forward Declares
00049 
00050 class btMotionState;
00051 class btQuaternion;
00052 class btVector3;
00053 class btRigidBody;
00054 class btSoftBody;
00055 class btTransform;
00056 class btDiscreteDynamicsWorld;
00057 class btDefaultMotionState;
00058 class btCollisionShape;
00059 class btSoftBodyWorldInfo;
00060 class btCollisionObject;
00061 typedef float btScalar;

00063 namespace Ogre

00065     class Entity;
00066     class SceneManager;
00067     class SceneNode;

00069 
00070 class PhysMotionState;
00071 
00072 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00073 /// @class ActorBase
00074 /// @headerfile physactor.h
00075 /// @brief This is the base class from which all the actors inherit.
00076 /// @details The actor classes store and manage all the relevant data regarding
00077 /// objects inside the PhysWorld.  They serve as a binder between the physics and
00078 /// graphics for objects and have functions that allow the manipulation of objects
00079 /// loaded into the PhysWorld.  Currently there are 4 actor classes: ActorBase,
00080 /// ActorDynRigid, ActorDynSoft, and ActorSta. @n
00081 /// ActorBase is a base class that serves as a template for the other three actor classes. @n
00082 /// ActorBase should never be created, as it lacks the functionality needed for most objects.
00083 ///////////////////////////////////////
00084 
00085 ///////////////////////////////////
00086 // Actual code
00087 
00088 class ActorBase {
00089     private:
00090         friend class PhysWorld;
00091 
00092         protected:
00093         PhysWorld* GameWorld;
00094 
00095         //abstraction for other libraries
00096         Ogre::Entity* entity;
00097         Ogre::SceneNode* node;
00098 
00099         btCollisionShape* Shape;
00100         btCollisionObject* CollisionObject;
00101 
00102         PhysMotionState* MotionState;
00103 
00104         /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00105         /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00106         /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't be called manually.
00107         /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the PhysWorld class.
00108         /// @param World Pointer to the physics world.
00109         virtual void AddObjectToWorld(PhysWorld* TargetWorld, btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* World) = 0;
00110         /// @brief Creates a trimesh shape from the mesh file.
00111         /// @details Makes a trimesh to be used as a collision shape in the physics world from a mesh file. @n
00112         /// This is automaticly called by the CreateShapeFromMesh function in child classes and shouldn't be called manually.
00113         void CreateTrimesh();
00114 
00115         //Ogre Management Functions
00116         /// @brief Creates an entity for the mesh file to be placed on a scene node.
00117         /// @details Creates an entity in the scene manager from the mesh file provided to be attached to a node in the graphical world. @n
00118         /// This function is called on by the Constructor, and shouldn't be called manually.
00119         /// @param Name Name of the actor.
00120         /// @param File File name of the graphical mesh to be used.
00121         /// @param Group Resource group where the graphical mesh can be found.
00122         void CreateEntity(PhysString name, PhysString file, PhysString group);
00123         /// @brief Creates a node for the entity in the graphical world.
00124         /// @details Creates a node in the scene manager to attach the actor's entity to within the graphical world. @n
00125         /// This function is called on by the Constructor, and shouldn't be called manually.
00126         void CreateSceneNode();
00127         /// @brief Sets the location of the graphical body.
00128         /// @details This will take a PhysVector3 and set the location of the actor within the graphical world. @n
00129         /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00130         /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00131         void SetOgreLocation(PhysVector3 Place);
00132         /// @brief Retrieves the location of the graphical body.
00133         /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the graphical world.
00134         PhysVector3 GetOgreLocation();
00135         /// @brief Sets the orientation of the graphical body.
00136         /// @details This will take a PhysQuaternion and set the orientation of the actor within the graphical world. @n
00137         /// This function is called on by the SetOrientation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00138         /// @param Rotation The quaternion representing the rotation of the actor.
00139         void SetOgreOrientation (PhysQuaternion Rotation);
00140         /// @brief Makes the actor visable.
00141         /// @details Adds the actor to all the nessessary graphics elements to make it visable on screen. @n
00142         /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't ever need to be called manually.
00143         void AttachToGraphics();
00144 
00145         //Bullet Management
00146         /// @brief Sets the location of the physics body.
00147         /// @details This will take a PhysVector3 and set the location of the actor within the physics world. @n
00148         /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00149         /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00150         virtual void SetBulletLocation (PhysVector3 Location);
00151         /// @brief Retrieves the location of the physics body.
00152         /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the physics world.
00153         virtual PhysVector3 GetBulletLocation();
00154         /// @brief Sets the starting location of the physics body within the PhysMotionState.
00155         /// @details Sets the starting location of the physics body within the PhysMotionState. @n
00156         /// This function is called on by the SetInitLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00157         /// @param Location The PhysVector3 representing the desired starting location for the actor.
00158         void SetBulletInitLocation (PhysVector3 Location);
00159         /// @brief Sets the orientation of the physics body.
00160         /// @details This will take a PhysQuaternion and set the orientation of the actor within the physics world. @n
00161         /// This function is called on by the SetOrientation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00162         /// @param Rotation The quaternion representing the rotation of the actor.
00163         virtual void SetBulletOrientation (PhysQuaternion Rotation);
00164 
00165         public:
00166         /// @brief Destructor.
00167         /// @details The class destructor.
00168         virtual ~ActorBase ();
00169         /// @brief Descriptive constructor.
00170         /// @details This constructor contains the basic information needed to make an actor.
00171         /// @param Name The name of the actor.
00172         /// @param File The 3d mesh file that contains the 3d model the actor will use.
00173         /// @param Group The resource group where the 3d mesh and other related files can be found.
00174         /// @param World Pointer to the PhysWorld this object will be added to.
00175         ActorBase (PhysString name, PhysString file, PhysString group, PhysWorld* World);
00176 
00177         /// @brief Manually sets the location of the actor.
00178         /// @details Calling this function prior to adding it to the PhysWorld will have no effect. @n
00179         /// In most situations you won't want to use this function, and instead produce movement through physics functions.
00180         /// @param X Location on the X vector.
00181         /// @param Y Location on the Y vector.
00182         /// @param Z Location on the Z vector.
00183         void SetLocation(PhysReal x, PhysReal y, PhysReal z);
00184         /// @brief Manually sets the location of the actor.
00185         /// @details Calling this function prior to adding it to the PhysWorld will have no effect. @n
00186         /// In most situations you won't want to use this function, and instead produce movement through physics functions.
00187         /// @param Place The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00188         void SetLocation(PhysVector3 Place);
00189         /// @brief Retrieves the location of the object.
00190         /// @details This function will retrieve the location of the object within the world.
00191         PhysVector3 GetLocation();
00192 
00193         /// @brief Sets the starting location of the actor.
00194         /// @details Calling this function after adding it to the PhysWorld will have no effect. @n
00195         /// This function will set where the actor will be located in the PhysWorld when it is first placed inside the world.
00196         /// @param Place The PhysVector3 representing the location.
00197         void SetInitLocation(PhysVector3 Location);
00198 
00199         /// @brief Sets the orientation of the actor.
00200         /// @details Sets the orientation of the actor via Quaternion parameters.
00201         void SetOrientation(PhysReal x, PhysReal y, PhysReal z, PhysReal w);
00202         /// @brief Sets the orientation of the actor.
00203         /// @details Sets the orientation of the actor via a Quaternion.
00204         /// @param Rotation The Quaternion representing the Rotation.
00205         void SetOrientation(PhysQuaternion Rotation);
00206 
00207         /// @brief Sets the state of the object to Kinematic.
00208         /// @details This function will set the object to a Kinematic Object. @n
00209         /// Kinematic Objects are like Static Objects but are also able to be moved directly by character controllers.
00210         void SetKinematic();
00211         /// @brief Sets the state of the object to Static.
00212         /// @details This function will set the object to a Static Object. @n
00213         /// Static Objects don't move or have any force applied to them, but are cabable of exerting force on other objects.
00214         void SetStatic();
00215 };
00216 
00217 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00218 /// @class ActorRigid
00219 /// @headerfile physactor.h
00220 /// @brief This is the actor class for Rigid Objects.
00221 /// @details This class should be used to make any rigid object that can be moved as a
00222 /// result of force.  Most objects will fall into this catagory.  A few examples of a
00223 /// Rigid Object: Boxes, Car Frames, Chairs, etc.  For Semi Rigid bodies that are
00224 /// deformable, like jello, it is better to use ActorSoft.
00225 ///////////////////////////////////////
00226 
00227 class ActorRigid: public ActorBase {
00228 
00229         protected:
00230         btRigidBody* physrigidbody;
00231         /// @brief Creates a rigid object for the actor.
00232         /// @details Creates a rigid object to be placed in the physics world later. @n
00233         /// This is automaticly called by the Constructor and shouldn't be called manually.
00234         /// @param PMass "PhysReal Mass" The mass of the object.
00235         void CreateRigidObject (PhysReal pmass);
00236         /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00237         /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00238         /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't be called manually.
00239         /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the PhysWorld class.
00240         /// @param World Pointer to the physics world.
00241         void AddObjectToWorld (PhysWorld *TargetWorld, btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* World);
00242         /// @brief Sets the location of the physics body.
00243         /// @details This will take a PhysVector3 and set the location of the actor within the physics world. @n
00244         /// This function is called on by the SetLocation function, and shouldn't be called manually.
00245 
00246         public:
00247         /// @brief Descriptive constructor.
00248         /// @details This constructor contains the basic information needed to make a Rigid Object. @n
00249         /// This class inherits from ActorBase.
00250         /// @param Mass The mass the object will have in the PhysWorld.
00251         /// @param Name The name of the actor.
00252         /// @param File The 3d mesh file that contains the 3d model the actor will use.
00253         /// @param Group The resource group where the 3d mesh and other related files can be found.
00254         /// @param World Pointer to the PhysWorld this object will be added to.
00255         ActorRigid(PhysReal mass, PhysString name, PhysString file, PhysString group, PhysWorld* World);
00256         /// @brief Destructor.
00257         /// @details The class destructor.
00258         virtual ~ActorRigid();
00259         /// @brief Creates a collision shape from mesh file.
00260         /// @details This function will read the location of every verticy in the mesh file and use that to
00261         /// construct a triangle mesh shape and attach it to this objects collision shape.
00262         void CreateShapeFromMesh();
00263 };
00264 
00265 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00266 /// @class ActorSoft
00267 /// @headerfile physactor.h
00268 /// @brief This is the actor class for Soft Objects.
00269 /// @details This class should be used to make any soft object that, like ActorRigid,
00270 /// can be moved or manipulated as a result of force.  Examples of soft objects are: Paper,
00271 /// Rope, and Cloth.  Semi Rigid bodies that are still somewhat deformable, like Jello,
00272 /// should be made as a soft object.
00273 ///////////////////////////////////////
00274 
00275 class ActorSoft: public ActorBase {
00276 
00277         protected:
00278         btSoftBody* physsoftbody;
00279         /// @brief Creates a soft object for the actor.
00280         /// @details Creates a soft object to be placed in the physics world later. @n
00281         /// This is automaticly called by the Constructor and shouldn't be called manually.
00282         void CreateSoftObject (btSoftBodyWorldInfo* softworldinfo, int nodecount, btVector3* nodearray, btScalar* massarray);
00283         /// @brief Adds the actor to the physics world.
00284         /// @details Adds the actor to the physics world. @n
00285         /// This is automaticly called by the PhysWorlds AddActor function and shouldn't be called manually.
00286         /// @param TargetWorld Pointer to the PhysWorld class.
00287         /// @param World Pointer to the physics world.
00288         void AddObjectToWorld (PhysWorld *TargetWorld, btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* World);
00289 
00290         public:
00291         ActorSoft();
00292         /// @brief Destructor.
00293         /// @details The class destructor.
00294         virtual ~ActorSoft();
00295         /// @brief Creates a collision shape from mesh file.
00296         /// @details This function will read the location of every verticy in the mesh file and use that to
00297         /// construct a triangle mesh shape and attach it to this objects collision shape.
00298         void CreateShapeFromMesh();
00299 };
00300 
00301 #endif
